Key Arguments: The bill undermines freedom of speech by creating two classes of citizens, privileging politicians, mainstream journalists, and educational institutions over regular citizens.
Excessive fines will lead to overly restrictive digital services, stifling free speech.
Determining truth is complex and the bill's broad definitions could lead to the removal of content that is actually true.
The bill imposes unreasonable legal risks and fines on individual website owners and companies.
Delegating legislative power to private entities is unconstitutional and violates freedom of political communication.
The bill dismisses the viewpoints of ordinary Australians, undermining the democratic process.
It could lead to reputational damage and financial penalties for digital platform providers and users, reminiscent of oppressive regimes.
The bill could skew the information landscape by benefiting only government-approved media outlets.
Notable Quotes: This bill effectively creates two classes of citizens...
Accurately determining what is true or false is a nearly impossible task.
The proposed delegation of legislative power to private entities... amounts to an unconstitutional abdication of legislative power.
The threats and potential interference outlined in the bill towards digital platform providers and users further erode our freedom and sense of security.
